element_texts.text:
Camp Harvey                                       Sunday
June 29, 1875
Mail arrived about 11 ½  a m
Corpl Irwin in charge apparently
about half drunk
No letters from any of the dear
ones.  Except Sis Molly who
writes from Salem.  Letter for
Genl Bradley - Soon after the
mail was opened Davenport
The Herald reporter came to
me with two letters one from
Ford tel op, at Ft Laramie
& one from Collins book keeper
informing him that the

into the care of Corpl Irwin
with the promise of $100 if he
delivered it 24 hours ahead.
Trout corroborating, all this 
I then sent for Corpl Irwin
& 5 men of the escort.
Corpl I. stated that he carried
this special package in the
bosom of his blouse until
he was driven by fear of its
getting wet to open the bag
& put it in with the regular
mail - at Beaver he met
Capt Bust, who asked to
examine the mail.  Corpl
I took it to him, opened it
& left it lying on the ground
in possession of Capt B

tel. dispatches sent in by D
had not been received - that
something was wrong - and he
asked me to investigate - It appears
that though Davenport hired
Joe Merwali to take his dispatches
in for him - Offering $100 - if
24 hours ahead of the mail
Spaulding preferred giving the
chance of earning that money
to Corpl Irwin - my mail
and Davenports - were given
to Spaulding who left 17th
((unclear) of that date)
at Camp Jeremy Spaulding
gave the specialty package
mine & Davenports Mail

& taking out the special
package, started for Ft Laramie
On his arrival there he went at
once to the Collins book keeper
who on opening the package
told him that some important
papers were missing - He
declares that no one but him-
self & Capt Bust touched the
mail from the time that Capt
Spaulding put it in his hands
until he gave it to the clerk.
Three of the soldiers with Corpl
I. state that they were with him
continually except when on
guard, that no one touched
the mail except him & Capt

While he went to see about his
horses - that when he came
back Capt B had got through
examining it - That the special
package appeared not to have been
touched & that he did it & the
other mail up together - that
Capt B asked him to remain
to enable him to write a letter
& that in compliance with
this request he staying there
4 1/2 hours longer than he wished.
That when he arrived at
The Niobrara he again
opened the sack or canvas
in which was the mail

Davenport & he soon got into hot words, which however stopped very soon - (Corpl I. had been sent for again by me to explain why he had the special package in his breast, or testified by Capt Muerson & which he said not only a temporary arrangement for fear some one might get at it--) Bust examined him, but soon got into a snarl. The Corpl insisting that he left the mail with Bust. The latter denying that the Corpl went away while the mail was being opened.

   Joe Nunwanbe examined

Bust.  The other two did
not see Capt B. open it as
they were on guard - I 
then sent for Capt Miniver.
He was on guard & did not
see Bust open the mail-
No officer was present -
Bust was next sent for
He acknowledged opening the
mail - but denies having
taken out anything except
two letters of Dr Law to the
Chicago Tribune - At his
request I sent for Davenport
& Corpl Irwin.

Burt may some 3 weeks ago foolish enough to threaten in the province of Bourke to take Davenports letters out of the mail. He is a rival correspondent & he had offer twenty Threat, motive & facts are against Bust -- for certain his honor as an officer, & standing as a man & the little likelihood of his selling himself so cheap --
Corpl Irwin is a drunkard not above a bribe - & someone may have induced him to fail to deliver the letters --

says he was present when the mail was opened. That it was untied by Corpl Irwin that Capt Bust once over the letters, took out two which Joe unclear were Dr Lawe's that Corpl Irwin then tied up the mail again that Corpl I. did not leave while the mail was open & that a lined out from the opening to the closing again was not over 3 or 4 minutes -- Show who took the letters? unclear Bust or Corpl Irwin.

I can do nothing but wait - Bust appears to be greatly troubled, & if guilty, acts innocent remarkably well. Corpl Irwin looks guilty & acts the same -- & is very impatient of our questions -- The affair has created a great excitement in camp -- Almost the whole day has been taken up in investigation with several pages in my book this morning before the mail came.
To bed late --

Davenport offered $100 for the delivery - Neither Bust nor MacMillan have any money to spare to pay for non-delivery. It is all a snarl now though the might of evidence is against Bust - yet I don't believe Bust did it -- & I suspect it may be seen so wrongfully that MacMillan is at the bottom of the disappearance & that Corpl Irwin is the agent --

unclear written good days work
More miners reported arrived making near 100 on this creek. I forgot to mention that Genl Bradly said in his letter recd yesterday that 2 cos of Cavy were to be sent up to clear out these miners - I shall be glad to have them cleared as they induce my men & the teamsters to steal provision & to sell to them -- & I am not convinced that some of them might want some of my stock - I'd rather risk ten Indians than one white thief -- No additional light on the lost mail matter. Bust seems quite downhearted

Camp Harney
Wednesday June 30, 1875
End of the fiscal year.
Uncle Sam short of cash.
Only partial payment to be made for June - When I woke up it was raining heavily. Has rained at intervals all day & until after 2 o clk quite hard. At 3 went to the Cos & Mustered them without inspection. It was not raining, but looked very suspicious. Wrote a good deal today in my book & will be able to finish the buffalo 

unclear good days work.

July 2, Friday
Bust & Dr. Lane went off today on a prospecting exped--
Went out for a ride with Spaulding, Joli, Bullock in Ford. Had a delightful day -- 
Got the joke on Spaulding who got lost rather turned round. Rode through very interesting country - Found a quartz lead which looks more like gold, than any thing I have seen. Dr. McGillicody  & party returned in evening - They have had a great trip - Heavy rain with hail at night - wrote letters to Genl Brady & Genl Crook dated tomorrow

& I've no doubt be in so --
Must get out & take some exercise -- 
__________________________________
July 1, 1875
Thursday - Camp Harney 
__   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___   ___
Ordered the horses for a ride but it looked so much like rain that I gave it up - wrote for an hour or two, & then read the papers.

  Nothing of news. All quiet in the Black Hills.
  Wrote at night - to bed 12 pm

Saturday - July 3, 1875
Old Joe came at 9 am, & said he would like to start at once - Told him he might at 12.M - Finished letter to Genl Crook & Bradley - wrote to Foster, Tvoty - Bourke & Cowdy Off Camp Robinson Signed My tir Rolls & Post Returns. Wrote several pages in my book & finished up the Buffalo except statistics of the hide & meat business -- As if in response to my suspicion of last night

16

Old Joe Menivale asked permission to go to Red Cloud agency - gave it & will send a mail by train. Told Genl B. about The Bust trouble & asked his assistance --- If the abstraction letters have been found at Ft Laramie it will show that Burt had nothing to do with the abstraction -- I think the Indian Ocean Man Macmillan & Corpl Irwin are the people to blame -    Meet when I am ---

by men in the regular mail.   the day after the fuss & that he (Corpl I) delivered them to the proper parties -- If this is true, it entirely relieves Burt of all suspicion in or connection with the affair & shows that Corpl Irwin was either bought by some one to take these letters from the special package & put them in the general mail,  or he did it. of his own accord in his maudlin drunken usual condition. My plan of keeping quiet will I sincerely hope develop the true facts - & I can congratulate

The Juter Ocean came over this evening to see me about the loss of Davenports mail -- He disclaims all knowledge & says that had he bought Corpl Irwin, he would readily acknowledge it now those the fair unclear of an Officer is involved. He is a very nice gentlemanly fellow & I believe he is telling the truth. Munson tells me this pm that he heard Corpl Irwin tell Spaulding that the two? letters missing were found

operations of the men -- some of them seem to be doing very well.  Visited the store room. Trout has all in excellent condition - Idah came to tell me about the impudence of the Trader & wanted to tie him up - after hearing his H's story; I told Hale that he was all wrong. That he must give up the stove the cause of quarrel & must not punish any camp followers -- I alone do that - He went off disgusted but I think convinced -- Read some of my Book to McMIllan & Munson. Both Complimentary

Burt on the present favorable aspect of his case.   Had one or two interesting talks with Dr Mc G, on the subject of mapping this country. He has ten times the sense that Jeremy has. He says that Morton will do very well -- all the youngsters have been to see me today -- Morton has not got his notes worked up. Dr Jaquette brought in the first strawberries of the season today. Went down to see the mining

A miner came in today with about $10. in very nice looking gold. Have arranged to buy $20 worth from him through Munson. Paid Fred his allowance for July -- Have not yet been able to get my rifle fixed. Shall be dead broke if it cant be done here & must send it in to Ft Laramie -- Manny Officers out today on hunts & mining parties

Got $50 from Trout today -- He would not take a check for it -- James wanted to have a settlement. I think he has mining on the brain & after getting his money will leave. I rather hope so. He is of little account -- certainly not worth $20 per month -- Ordered Company Inspections tomorrow am. Joe left with mail at 12:30. Has been a cool & pleasant day. Then in a.m. about 10- 63°.  To bed 12 pm Nap in afternoon

day. Highest then 52° -  lowest between Sun & Sun day - 40° -  No 4th July worth a cent. The scientists made a huge bonfire at night & the youngsters not to be outdone got permission to send up some rockets. When the third had gone off however, I found such decided symptoms of alarm among the stock that I stopped it -- McMillian Inter ocean man came & begged my manuscript about Buffalo. He wants to put

Camp Harney D. T.
Sunday July 4th 1875
Raining when I woke up. Had to countermand inspection. Orders issued for Cap Hawley & 45 enlisted men to start tomorrow escort to scientists 4 wagons. Also to Foster to take 20 men & map the country far west on the Camp Jeremy road. 1 wagon = Raining at intervals & very cold all day

unclear missing letters in the regular mail at Fort Laramie or took them to the book keeper at Collins -- As soon as Burt comes in I will send for Corpl Irwin & finish the thing up -- 

  If this cold rainy weather holds on much longer I will have to modify my opinion of the perfect climate -- Though the rain is good for the grass. 
  Made map of this camp & vicinity which I think good - got to bed 11 1/2 pm --

it in his paper as exactly from a forthcoming work by Col Dodge. I gave it to him - for I can take no harm from having a little unknown & puffing in advance.

   If the buffalo part takes, I have every reason to compatitive myself, for I think it the least interesting part of my book. Wrote a little today -- started on wild cattle --
 Spaulding says that Corpl Irwin told him that he himself found the

before 12 - & is pleasant day.
__________________________________
Sunday July 6, 1875
_____________-               __________________               _____________
Cold last night, but slept well, by addition of overcoat to my bedding -- Clear warm day. Started out at 10 am with Ford Took Spaulding & old Bullock for an investigation of the canon of the Creek. Rode down it some 6 miles. Found the canon very deep & crooked. Had a long shot at a deer running. Evidently shot it through the ear. It went off shaking its head -

23

Monday July 5 1875
Capt Mawbry got off with the scientists at about 9 am. For his unclear his 20 men left by 8. All are comfortably off & I hope will have a good trip. They have 10 days rations. Spent the morning making a map of the vicinity of Camp Harney. I made on last night but it had several serious errors, so I discarded it. I think I've got a nearly perfect one now. 

  Wrote some in my book, & took a short nap. It was raining in the morning or I would have gone out riding. Clears off before 12, & is pleasant day

getting into the canon again on our way home, I came on a White Tail Doe & shot her through but too far back. She did not run but could do so - & I put three more bullets into her before she would lie down. Bagged & brought her in. My first deer on this trip & my first White-Tail in several years -- All my hunting in the Dept of the Missouri Army among Black Tails --

Turned off the canon to the right & came into a lovely pack country. Following it to the South East for some 4 miles. Had a 600 yds shot at a Black Tail Buck - put my bullet between his legs not hitting him. As we did not care to see the Cheyenne we turned back - The country is one of the most beautiful & picturesque in the Hills - so far as we have seen.

several misses after he had the double trigger fixed & thought it shot to the right. A fair trial however convinces me that the sights are exact for live shooting - All my shots were excellent line shots but all but scratched out a little high - would have taken game every time. Nap in afternoon Lovely day. Warm & lazy. Went down to look at the miners. We have got a sluice box in & started on making secure. We will now soon know exactly what is to be

I sleep now under only 2 blankets & a comforter 
______________________________________________________
Monday July 7, 75
Up on time. lovely am --
after breakfast cut up my deer. Sent have to Burt another to spaulding -- 

 Went out to practice with my rifle.  Am off in shooting for most of practice. Trout fired the rifle

Thursday - July 8, 1875
__________________________________________________
About 11 1/2 pm last night when I had finished my Diary and had done a really good good nights work of some 10 pages on my book I heard far off a sound as of horses feet. I got up & stuck my head out, but could then hear nothing. When I laid down I heard it again. Finally after near 15 minutes it became so distinct

expected from Black Hills mining on French Creek - Two miners left yesterday for Ft Laramie - disgusted - They say they have prospected the Hills thoroughly & are satisfied they wont pay - They tried to live as teamsters but failing sold their blankets to the Herald man & "cut out" - Many a man will be disappointed like these but no one will take warning or advice. Each must see for himself Sluice box 2.25

they came at
& yet I must have heard them fully a mile off & my ears are none of the best. 

  Jeremy was very communicative & very much pleased with his success on his trip. He has found a better country & more gold even than here. He says we are in the poorest part of the Hills, except in timber alone - We had a long talk this morning. He is learning rapidly. He said he was much pleased with the work of the soldiers here & that if I would permit

that I got up & this time on thrusting my head out I found several horsemen not far from my tent.
I challenged & Jeremy answered. He dismounted sent his escort to the unclear & I gave him a shake down on my floor - This singular & difficult to account for my hearing the horses steps so far off. The road is soft the thick turf -- scarcely beaten. They came at a walk.

that the exertions of all
unclear would back him more of the country in a week than he unassisted could find out in 3 months.

  He appeared much struck by this view & said he would do all he could hereafter to interest the men in his work -
  After the mail comes, I am to send off a good party with him - Burt & Munson are wild to go. I copied my last nights work & pushed the subject of wild cattle. Spent an hour in Burt's with this pen Saw Marcy's book for the first time, & discovered

him, he would utilize their labor -- I told him that I was not only willing but that I had often wondered he had never thought of it before that he had it in his power by showing interest & sympathy in the work of the men to convert every soul of this command into his active & valuable assistant.

  That he could only see with one pair of eyes, which then could see with -- 400 pairs & that the exertions of all

unclear yesterday & I am in a bad way. Jeremy's party all came in this pm, out of provisions & looking unclear forlorn & hard worked. 

 Had a pleasant party at my tent in evening -- Chatted & told stories -- words lined out Read Blackwoods Magazine all afternoon till dinner. Found it very stupid ir? I am stupid. Too heavy for my digestion -- To bed about 11 1/2 pm - Sluice box, faithfully worked by 5 men. only $1.10 dont pay.

that he has got my Black Beaver story. Must write to Potter & see who it belongs to. If it is Potters story I will hold on to it for I have got a better story than unclear.

  Brought the book up & read it at night. It is very interesting in its facts & knowledge, but dull in detail & unclear of telling - The day has been pleasant but a long one to me. I am getting two of the camp - My watch broke

move over to those Creeks unclear troops - He needs the Infantry Cos to do the work. that his new fit of sensibleness enables him to see is to his advantage 

  No mail - something must be wrong. If not in tomorro will send out - Wrote some little but have been very good for nothing lounged, read novels, Wrote snatches now on description of Bk HIlls now on something else. In short my mind was in a lazy or at least a pickle now. & I accomplished nothing satisfactory.
  It rained hard for two hours this morning & I suppose that had something to do with it for

Friday July 9 1875
Had old Joe up this am (California Joe) & a long talk with him about getting wagons from here to Spring Ck & Rapid. He says it can be done without much work, but seems to think it impossible to go up either Spring Rapid or Box Elder.

  I must go out & do some looking about for myself. Jeremy is very anxious to move over to those Creeks with

Saturday July 10 1875
_______________________                    _______________________                      _____________________________
Rained hard nearly all night. I was awake just often enough to hear it & enjoy it. The pattering of rain on tent or roof  is to me like most delicious of lullabies -- Tent is excellent. Does not leak at all -- tho no fly is up -- 
Wrote note this morning on the book - getting off about 10 pages of Elk very comfortably 
No mail - Recd a pencil note from Lt Foster - out

I am constitutionally opposed to work on a rainy day. I suppose this comes from being brought up with "Niggers". Took a walk in afternoon after owners met Trout & Ford. Advised the cattle sat with the Dr for some time Had short nap before dinner. I do wish the mail would come so I could decide on something. Jeremy brought some very fine looking quartz from last trip -I learn that 26 miners go back tomorro. Satisfied with the prospects - No work, no pay --

This letter & rumor coming on my lack of mail. Set me up a little & I ordered Capt Russell & Co. to start tomorrow am to unravel the difficulties, bring in my mail party or at least see what the trouble is. 
He takes 60 men & 3 wagons 10 days rations & 10 unclear at 3 pounds per day for arrival
16 miners with ten wagons came in today - 26 miners said to have left disgusted.
Has been a pleasant day.
Jeremy & quite a party around my camp fire tonight -

surveying?  He reports Indian sign in plenty, & that the prairie has been unclear all about the Cheyenne. There is also news on a report coming from the miners who came in yesterday or today, that the Cheyennes had stolen all the stock at Ft Hartsuff on the Loup. & that Genl Crook had ordered all the Cheyennes out of the Dept & ordered the troops to kill them whenever found.

found an excellent not clear They go on to Spring Creek to a point about 25 miles from here - Jeremy interior to put in Sluice boxes & test those digging thoroughly On my return issued the necessary orders & got all ready for the start. Made up my mind to make one more effort to find Harneys Peak -- So ordered an early breakfast tomorrow - 

  Spaulding sat up with me at night. to the unclear hours

July 11 - Sunday -
____________________________                         ________________________                  __________________________
Jeremy very uneasy at losing time. So to comfort him I ordered the unclear Infy Cos & 6 Cavalry to start with him tomorrow morning. 

  Must out myself in the morning with Foote & Ford & old Bratton the puckered look out a road for them.
  Just about 10 miles & found an excellent

places which we believed to be Harney directly in our front - After immense difficulty & fatigue succeeded in gaining the base of the perpendicular rock of the most southern of the Peaks. Trout rushed up on foot, but I preferred trying the other which appeared higher, & up which I could unclear - At last I reached the top to find myself at least 100 feet higher than Trouts peak. Although it was cloudy - unclear raining

Monday July 12 -
___________________       _______________________
Burt & Cosud? got off about 7:30 -- Soon after started with Ford Foote Trout Old Bratton for Harneys Peak. I had seen what every body said was the peak & taken careful bearings so was sure of no failure.

  Travelled nicely to the first [[unclear] & crossed it with some difficulty, which was rewarded by the sight of the noble

separated by unclear
canon - I made a strenuous effort to get on to it, but the ground was so difficult, & the ravines so deep & steep, that I was forced to give it up, for fear we would not get back to camp before night.

   Harney's peak is undoubtedly the highest point on the eastern edge of the Black Hills -- but it is so very singularly situated that it cannot be seen from the South or West.

a little the view was worth superb: I got out my compass & commenced to get bearings when happening to look behind me to the north west I was disgusted to find a peak yet higher & which from its unclear was undoubtedly the true Harney.

  It was not more than 3 miles off  but was separated by profound

pretty nearly broke down  unclearlack of wind. We reached Camp 4: 30. After a most unclear trying but very satisfactory day. Covered by everything. I now know where Harney's Peak is & can go to it if I wish - but I dont think I will wish --- Just as I started out this am I recd a note from Burt saying that the notorious carpenter? had arrived bringing artillerymen that Genl Crook & the

We started to return 1:30. It rained in showers every little while - & we had to go through dense thickets which drenched us in spite of our over coats - The route was so very bad coming down that we had to walk nearly all the way - & also in the gorges. The bushes were so thick that riding was out of the question. I was pretty nearly broke down

& think I will ---
unclear line
Burt at his own request. After dinner had a nap.  & at night copied up my work of 9th - Kept me up till late. Carpenter brought 44 men with him & says that there are thousands of miners on the road here -

  Old man Bratton a very intelligent man. Has been a miner all his life - Several times worth $100,000 - now my unclear American - & the miners fortune

paymaster would be here today. Didn't believe him & went on -- On my return I got a letter from Russell detailing Carpenters news, but found no Genl Crook --  I expect they will be here tomorro -- Delany's pony was stolen two nights ago & today was found in a miners camp. I ought to go for them someway. think I will ---

the unclear pole -- Had no unclear familiar lighting on the bed & so noisy that I could  not get to sleep. So got up & let him out. It was just after sunrise & a bright beautiful a.m. when I woke up the second time it was raining & that has kept up all morning. Burt sent in an Orderly with some letters, & a report of the lightning yesterday striking his son, two men & a horse, all of whom had taken refuge under a pine tree to escape a heavy storm of rain & hail - The horse was killed. Burts son &

Tuesday - July 13 - 75
_____________  ____________________    _________________
Woke up rather late somewhat stiff after yesterdays jaunt -- mapped out the discoveries of yesterday. Took all the morning as my previous map was on correct. I should have said I was  waked up very early by a noise in my tent. in opening my eyes found a young snow bird had got in & was answering himself eating the flies which congregate near the unclear pole - Had no

all round ------------------------------
The man Carpenter who arrived yesterday with his miners has filled the camp with all sorts of rumors about Genl Crooks coming, & the doings of the Indian Conversionism. It is not necessary to record them as they are only rumors -- Took a good nap in afternoon At night wrote for some hours & pretty nearly finished up my Elk business -- I shall have to modify my expressions about this climate -- There is decidedly too much rain. Must to bed
let ---------------

one of the men, Welch - were struck in the same way on the cheek the fluid passing down the body & out at the sole of the foot leaving a hole like a rifle bullet in the shoe - They were practically paralyzed afterwards & each had a blister on the sole of the foot like a burn - but were this morning doing well. The other man escaped with only a knock down. It was a very narrow escape all round --------------

cloud that burst over Burt & hence it must
be raining heavily, but heard no thunder.

  Burt says 20 trees were struck in an area of 2 acres. I was 2000 feet above him, but not more than six miles away. Query -- Does the sound of thunder only pass downwards and laterally? ---


Newberry Library logo stamped in lower right corner

while we were on the top of the Mountain yesterday we had a little rain but not enough to prevent our admiring the appearance of the clouds & storms below us - we could see half a dozen stories going on at once in different sections & the rain, a lightning far below us. We heard but little thunder & no loud reports I saw the storm cloud that burst over

Took walk with Ford after dinner
Thursday - July 15, 75
_____________                  ______________-             ____________________
Pleasant day but somewhat  cloudy in a.m. About 9½ am mounted our horses. Fred Trout Foote & Dr. Law & started up the creek. Visited the mining operation first. Harrison's party is doing well. They have got in a good sluice box & are working hard. The clean up of yesterday's work was a little over 31 dollars. They are all  sanguine. Went on to Frainor's claim. He has only a cradle, & 2 men besides himself, but

Wednesday - July 14 -
________________________              _____________________              ______________________
Quiet warm day -
Wrote in the morning & finished up the Elk -- 

  Was visited by a Capt of a mining party who was drunk & terribly polite -- He bored me for half an hour & left -- 
  Had a nap in afternoon 
Visited spaulding & other officers & gassed. Nothing new, & no rain today -- Took walk with Ford after Dinner

5 or 600 in the Hills.
a great number of men in different parties but very few are  doing any work. Continued up the creek for about 9 miles from Camp then struck north. Struck Custer's road in about 2 miles at the big bend. Crossed it & countered N.E. until we also crossed Burt's trail. I then turned sharp to the east, crossed the creek & struck into a canon by which I believed I could make a near cut to camp. succeeded admirably & proceed a good north. Corrected my map of that country

thinks he has the best claim on the creek. The strippings are at least six feet, but his gravel averages 10 cents to pan. He has a ditch ready & says he will begin to sluice as soon as the others of his party return from prospecting. About one hundred men have left the creek in the last week & have scattered over all the Hills looking for something better. 

  Miners are coming in at a great rate & there must be 5 or 600 in the Hills.

found the orderly but no horse. Blew him up. Sent party with orderly as guide to look for horse & they brought him in just at dark. We got back at 5 pm after a most delightful jaunt. Saw 4 deer, but got none.

  Found Newton & McGillicuddy house. They have had a hard trip. The country passed over by them is very rough but they have many discoveries. A new creek with a free cascade of 50 feet. A merciful one --

Left Trout's compas on top of unclear & had to go back for it. A red squirrel had the tenacity to show himself & I shot his head off tho he was high up on a pine --

  Overtook Trout in & the Dr who had gone on. Trout had shot the head off a spike grouse & killed a young chick -- The Dr had let his horse get away from him & was footing it manfully, having sent the orderly after horse

the Platte on Friday --
Friday July 16, 75
______________                  ______________________                       ______________________________
James waked me up this morning with the mail & a very disappointing one. A very satisfactory letter from Father & Mother was really all  Nothing from Tooty either to myself or Fred. Nothing from Genl Crook & only a wise note from Gl Bradley. But he sent me a batch of papers & I have been reading them all day - & tortured my eyes - Foster goes out

Morton is doing nicely, & is very much interested in his work. McG says he has a good map -- They start again in a day or two to explore the canon of French Sandus, a hunter & unclear came in from Ft Laramie today & says that Genl Crook is not coming. that the paymaster is in St Pauls Min. My cousin attending a Court Martial & that vessels only crossed the Platte on Friday --

of Burt a long way. He
pretty thickly but takes his spite out at Jeremy.. The latter brought it on himself by acting like an overbrown boy.
Beecher Tilton a Nigger -- & the American Rifle Shots beat the Irishman.

  Miners coming in droves.
  They are seriously not to be interfered with. Rain all day. Sometimes very hard -- 
  It is rather too moist for a fine climate -- Chatted & read til late -- Sent mail to Infy & Jeremy --

tomorrow with the scientists to work up French Ck Canon,

 After that they return here & we will all leave soon for a Camp on Spring Creek.
  Foster brought me in a good map of his last scout. He does remarkably well for a beginner & will make an excellent map maker if he sticks to it. Davenport's letter in the Herald is very excellent, better than those of Burt a long way. He

Early this am & comes
unclear
fort. I complimented him on his letter deprecating the compliments to myself. Found an attack on me in Chicago Tribune. A first Class D. F. or rather uses lice as a means of attack on the Indian Ocean. Took it to McMillan & told him to go for that fellow - & gave him also an extract from my written report - Burt sent the mail orderlies back & they arrived at night.

  Jeremy also sent a man in who reported 11 at night

Saturday July 17, 65
____________________________________________________
Ther. 9 am 60° - 12. M. 67° - 10 pm 52
___________________________________________________
Rain again & could not ride
Foster & McGillicuddy got off about 10 am to explore French Ck Canon. Worked on map & have got an excellent one of the vicinity of their Camp.

  Russell came in with Co about 10 am Has had a very pleasant time. Davenport came in very early this am & comes

July 18, 75
___________________________________________
Thur 8 am 58°. 2 pm 72, 12 pm 62 
___________________________________________
Gave all necessary order for the movements & for mail party. 
About 9½ am started on an exploring exposition. Spaulding old Bullock Trout Fred & myself. Went to explore the Canon I found the day before yesterday.

  It was a Splendid Canon. The rocks on sides were not continuous but were all the more unclear unique & they towered to the higher of fully 1000 feet. After a rather hard pull through thickets

with information that he had struck big gold and a telegram to Interior Dept reporting the find & requesting me to send it to Ft Laramie as soon as possible --

  Lawson applied for leave of absence, will send him in with a party beside the lower camp after dinner - 
  Miners coming in by scores --
  Have had to order them out of camp & from the vicinity of camp - to preserve the grass & water -

at the companion - Harney
less than an hour we were seated (not very comfortably for the top was a bare crag, fitted only for an eagles nest) on the very summit. The views were superb. I unfortunately had left my glass at Camp. So had to depend entirely on the naked eye. Made several sketches - which amount to very little - as I only sketch to my own understanding. I however got a good view of the geography of that part of the Hills. We were 2½ hours in

& over rocks, we just got to the beginning of the end. Then Spaulding backed out & turned back with Bullock. Trout had half a notion to do so too but was ashamed. I went on & in half a mile down was rewarded by coming on one of the finest views of the Hills. We were all at once between Harney & a comparison of almost equal pretension & being so near I could not resist but went at the companion. Harney

men to camp upon it for I want the grass for my stock.

  Wrote long letter to Tooty just after dinner - Went visiting afternoon - unclear & Co arrived today while I was gone -- Also a new Lieut of K Co - whose name I have not yet been able to find --
  unclear he came up to see me after dark -- gassed & chatted a while when they went off & I went to writing Wrote to Father & Mother & brother to unclear about an expense

returning & the way for part of the distance was very rough so we could not have made over 8 miles. As soon as I got back went to work on my map.  Laid down a little while before dinner - after dinner worked again & have got a nice map -- 

  Several miners called about their claims & camps -- I wont let them work claims just above camp because I want food, water for my comd I do not permit

& are just unclear enough to be at unclear all the time -Ordered some miners away --. They being to near - They are watching a claim & promised neither to pan nor graze stock until I unclear the whole crowd left -- so I gave them permission to remain. Tired & sleepy at night, but went to bed very late -- as I had much to do -- This diary be my last act before going to sleep ---

unclear. Short note to Genl Crook & one to Bradley. Told him the miners accuse him of speculating on the ferry. He will be hopping unclear Jule blood Indian near camp today. They were sitting near a citizen who was panning gold - I went up & spoke to them - they were very civil - but I had no interpreter to talk to them. They are with some whites - half breeds

over the mountain and not sorry I did so because I got another idea of the mountain system - but it was hard work. The Canons are in reverse - & the country as broken as any I have ever taken a horse over. After a deal of wandering over rocks & through brush I got tired of the stream I was on & struck across some low foot hills - after some time we came down to the Creek & thence

Monday July 19, 1875
__________________   __________________   _____________________-
Ther 6.30 . 57° - 10 pm 52
Camp No 18 - 
______
Broke camp 8.45 with  2 Cos. & Hdqr - Spaulding took comd & train via road to Custers Park & thence north by Burts road down a branch of Spring Ck -- Foote Fred & I went over our trail of yesterday - over the mountain

was first on top --
was not so anxious to go up Harney's, which I could easily have done, for the reason that it had been unclear last year by Custer & party. Fords peak is only second to Harney -- 

  There is here in Spring Ck about about three times the water than is in French at Camp Harney. unclear are everywhere. They seem to have sprung up as if from a seed source by

westward to find the road. Found it. Sent an orderly to see where Spaulding was - & then turned north - went about a mile and a half & went into camp, in a lovely valley.

 There is something I've unclear in the idea, that we stept where no foot of white man ever trod before - Yesterday I felt it on the peak of our discovery - which I shall name Fred's peak, as he was first on top --

is a strong
sot along pretty well --

 Trout has had most trouble. as the unclear always has if he is any account -- One wagon overturned. The road is fair - Country lovely. Made 14½ miles. Tried fishing, but I think there are no fish here. I did not see even a minnow -- Saw no game at all -- To bed at 10 o ck pm

Some unclear We have seen more than a dozen parties today. Some going some coming. In wagons with [?pack....?] or on foot. The country is filled with them Camp Harney being in a sort of pocket or out of the way.   We were not aware of the stream that was pouring to our west -- 

  We are in it now & it is a strong one

They are a lazy lot. {{unclear]] the large men of them are loafers at home & came out here expecting to pick up gold without work -- The usual picture is one man leisurely digging in a hole, while a dozen others are setting around looking on & commenting.

  After an hours march this am I found miners camps. The occupants of which were yet burrowed in profound slumbers.
  Eating sleeping & loafing are the principle unknown & I am sure I today passed 50 idle miners to

Tuesday July 20. Camp 19
___________          _______________            ____________________
Thur - 6 - 60°  3 pm 84° - 3 30 62°
10 pm 58° ______________________
________________________________________
Broke camp 6 am - Started a head of the crowd & reached Burt's Camp 8:30 - Found all well - Spaulding & Cavy came in 9:20. The wagons did not get in until 1 pm

 Camped about ½ mile above Burt passed miners every half mile of the whole trip. There must be an immense number in the Hills but they are a lazy lot. unclear

I have seen a very great many of them.

  In coming into this creek we have entered a different country in many respects. The timber is not so good as on French - We have come down, I think somewhere near a thousand feet. The soil is equally good & the season is unclear advanced.
  The grass is heavin? if anything. The berries are ripe. The weather is much warmer. The changes greater &

every one that was working - There is not a sluice box on the creek. The general miner registers a claim & sits down on it until some man on a neighboring claim on the same bar shall have dug a hole & panned out the dirt on bed rock. If not favorable the general miner pulls up stakes & locates on some other bar, to wait for its development by same process. They are a lazy worthless set so far

over & selected camp. It is a very pretty & good one - as all our camp are in these Magnificent Hills the very finest loveliest country I have ever campaigned in. We had fairly gotten into camp when there was premonition of a storm. I laid down, read a bit & got to sleep, but was waked by the heat. Tootie at the there & was as troubled to find that it reached 84°

more sudden -- The nights are more damp. There was a very heavy dew this am. It is a better agricultural country than French Ck & South -but not so fine a climate - This stream is at least 4 times as large as French & has much more fall. but the bottom is not so wide & there is less arable land.

  I took lunch with Munson who is a good fellow, & a gentleman when he's

Wrote a letter to Cap Hawley about Foster & his work -- Soon after all the officers called & we spent a very pleasant evening. The scenery along the road today was fine especially some views of Harneys peak & the neighboring mountains ---

  A good deal of game in camp tonight -- both black & white tail deer --
  General course today a little east of north

a very short time after a thunder shower broke over us & in 30 minutes the ther fell to 62-- 22° in half an hour ---

 After a good unclear off a saddle of unclear such are by Burt. I had a fire built. California Joe came up soon after. He gave me very favorable accounts of our road tomorro -- & wanted to go with me. Told him if he would show me a good

Jeremy stole a march on the officers in camp here & did not tell them that he had asked for me to send in a mail -- He sent a man (soldier) out of Burts Camp to me without asking B's permission - slipped him off in fact at night -- He is undoubtedly a low shabby fellow with mean instincts --

a very short time after Distance 10 miles-- 
Had to cross stream a great many times. It canons several times & makes the road difficult 
3 miles below this camp it canons again & is impossible for wagons. In strike off here - a little east of north for Rapid ---
Burt is mad as a hornet & I would not be surprised if he gave Jeremy a piece of his mind ---

Plenty of Bull frogs in the stream - only suckers & Dace in Spring Ck as in French.

  Rain in July -- 4 5, 7, 10, 12, 13 16, 17, 20 - 

_______________________________________________-
4. 7. 16 --17, rainy days all day at intervals --
The others showers more or less severe --

pimty - Butterflies moths not abundant - Ants numerous especially a red-bellied biting ant - Sarp wing cased bugs of wonderful character in of several varieties abundant
______

 Flower - very pretty - wild roses all along creek

- Tiger lillies on side hills
- Many other varieties.
- No snakes or toads - Some mosquitoes in day, but none at night -

Game --

 white tail deer - few

______

 spike grouse - very few
 squirrels ----      "       "

Wood chucks - some ground squirrels - very small - plenty mice - observant - 
---Jusich nuisances?
Flies of all sorts - blue bottle, sand biting, & horse flies most or all sweat --

See journal of 13 July for research on storms --

Govt in Spring Creek sends salaries to Ind. Agent is actuated by same nations as UPRR, as told nearby a monument official. They gave Conoucton as unclear salary as possible for as they steal all they possibly can unknown. The less the salary they cost

Waters back on Thursday The streams which start south from the vicinity of Harneys peak soon turn to the eastward. While those that now flow eastward from the western rise are so crooked that they must in cutting a new way for themselves have used all the Calesal Channels into which their waters neglect have precipated where damned up.

I modify the foregoing by now thinking that the original Island was  very broken but with a masked unclear chain on its Eastern Side within an average of 15 to 30 miles of the ocean. These had been cut by water & the drainage was from the unclear heights. The highest part of the Island was then about Harneys peak & the unclear streams flowed westward. The upheaval turned the

of mountains. The streams finally reach the plains having cut their way through from 15 to 30 miles of hard granite through channels so extremely crooked that I can account for the course by no other hypothesis than that given. Not a stream takes its rise in the western rim but cuts its way through the eastern mountain by canons from 500 to 1000 feet deep & so crooked that at sometime of its course it travels to every point of the compass
dammed up.

were cutting for themselves. New channels to the Eastward. Sometimes they are for a few miles all old north or south Chanel of the island streams. But constantly  forced eastward by the declivity or circulation. They force themselves constantly forced eastward by the new inclination. The waters are compelled in almost every direction by opposing unclear moving for a few miles an old north or south channel of the Island stream. Now cutting it may by a deep & narrow gorge of mountains. The stream

cut new channels for unclear starting was the topic of the Great unclear view or mesa. The water tore its way over there channels words lined out though the conformationally soft face of the new upheaval carrying with it immense quantities of mud & debris. This caught in the old channels & courses of the original island or in the widened ballup gradually filled them up until this unclear site of the HIlls is what we find it an immense secondary upheaval sloping eastward & getting thinner? & thrown until we finally come to the primary neck of the original island. During all this time these new formed streams

surrounded by an [unclear] view of secondary formation the whole sloping from west to east -- + lined out: while The rains which fell upon this island before upheaval unclear cut its surface into innumerable channels, apparently from [lined out: a general center to the outward] about the curling to the north & south = When the [[words lined out: old [unclear] ]] general upheaval took place. The whole new formation original island and surrounding river were tilted to the Eastward. The rains which continued to fall had to cut new channels for [?Thencelong?]

once an Island surrounded by deep water. In unclear of time the water was shorn of this Island were pulled higher & higher by deposits torn from it & unclear islands when these deposits had become many thousand feet thick they rise by a great unclear of nature thrust up. The original Island probably going up with them, but not be only to the height that the new elevation attained on the west.

  The island now appeared as before in itself but compatible

their horses so they dare not turn them loose - The old Indian said further that the Indians do not care at all for this country & would have sold or given it to the settlers long ago, if it had not been for the "square men" about the Reservation urging them to make a big fuss & get a big price --

polu - During this time the "buchi" hunt. The reasons given for the Indians not coming here are:  that there is nothing to come for there being but little game. that it rains very frequently & the Indians dont like rain.

  That it thunders & lightens with terrible force striking & over throwing trees & setting fire to the woods. The Indians dont like this - ? That the flies are terribly bad & torment

Two half breeds & an old Sioux named Robe-Raiser spent a week with California Joe on Rapid Creek looking for god. The old Indian told Joe that though fifty years old he had never been in the Black Hills before. He said that the Indians never came here, except occasionally to hunt. That when passing North or South in the fall the caravan come in for a

A good many miners have come in recently. They think that an effort will be made to capture them & are scattered in the hills where they will have to be hunted like rabbits - if taken out - We miss Bourke greatly.  Wish Kindest regards to men & all friends.

             Most sincerely yours
                                      Richard Dodge
                                                Lt Col 22 Infy
                                                          and

Genl Geo Crook

      unclear Dept
Not an Indian so far ---

it is the deadest country I have ever seen.

  The scientific party is very busy. Mr Jeremy is out prospecting. Dr. McGillicuddy returned today from a 7 days mapmaking trip -- & starts again on 5th. They hope to be through here by 15 or 20, when he moves to the north & west -- The Com'd is in excellent health & fine conviction . I have no trouble at all. Every one seems anxious to do his best when on duty & the whole affair is so far a delightful picture

These however are not frequent. Should a military post in the HIlls be decided on, I recommend a large Mily? Reservation both for lumber & hay.

  The hills & valleys are covered with flowers. The number & familys of which is wonderful Yet then are in this vicinity.  Scarcely any birds & no game at all. I took a ride today of at least 15 miles - Saw one hawk, one robin, about a dozen sparrows & 3 unclear ground squirrels. Beautiful as it is

& there are no burrs or briars to injure the wool. The water is unsurpassed, pure cold & abundant. The timber varies greatly. In some places it is very fine large straight stocks, free from knots & not wind shaken

  In other places it is unclear knotty & unfit for sawing.
  Then appears the much more good timbers than there is, but then is an immense deal - I have found a few good hay bottoms where the grass

20 days have not yet cut through the sod. 

  There is no dust, & we have not yet been troubled with any high winds -- The grazing is splendid every where, save among the pines & to the tops of the hills- There is no finer country for stock raising in the world if we may judge by appearances -- Those who claim to know say that it is the finest sheep range they have ever seen

We have had rains at least 3 times a week & 2 or 3 regular eastern rainy days when from morning to night it came down in a steady pour. You will see that there can be no necessity for irrigation. The soil of the bottoms is a deep rich loam, as fine for agricultural purposes as any I have ever seen. The grass is magnificent, & set so deeply, & the roots so completely matted that our horses though tied to the

bits of scenery, perfect pictures similar it is true in general characteristic but constantly different in detail -

 The climate as far as we have experienced is well nigh perfect. Some days have felt warm, but the thermometer has showed no higher than 78° since we got into the Hills - The evenings are somewhat damp & the nights Sometimes rather cool for best life - 3 or 4 blankets being readily comfortable

If many people rush in here there will be great misery & suffering - The placer mining will not pay a crowd - and the leads, even if they eventually pay, will require capital to develop. People who come here for gold will generally be disappointed.

  The country is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen. There is little variety in the scenery but wherever one looks at one encounters charming bits of

looking very favorable we have so far been unable to assure ourselves whether or not it contains gold. One thing may be relied on. No such specimens as are reported to have been taken to Sioux City - by miners from the Black Hills ever came from such [?ledges?] as we have found -- No specimen found by us has shown any gold under the microscope  but our specimens have generally been taken from the surface

On all the streams tested gold has been panned out in small quantities - A sluice box run for about 4 hours today by 3 men, yielded %1.25 - The earth may unclear from the bank of the creek, without stripping from the top to 3 or 4 feet down   My opinion is that no man will ever get rich from placer mining in the Blk Hills, but a considerable number of men may make fair maps.

  The hills are full of rotten quartz veins, the rock

Camp Harney
                                                                                                                                July 2, 75

Dear General,

   After 3 weeks in the Blk Hs I am enabled to give you more satisfactory information in regard to their resources & value than I could in my previous letters -- Gold is the most important question. It is found every where in the French region so far as we have been able to investigate but not in such quantity as will warrant a rush of people.
